# O\*NET OnLine features

## Introduction

Welcome to your tool for career exploration and job analysis!


O\*NET OnLine has detailed descriptions of the world of work for use by job seekers, workforce development and HR professionals, students, developers, researchers, and more!


Find, search, or browse across 900+ occupations based on your goals and needs. Then use comprehensive reports to learn about requirements, characteristics, and available opportunities for your selected occupation.


Take advantage of the customized [OnLine Help](https://www.onetonline.org/help/) feature available throughout the site. Or, use the available [Desk Aid](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/deskaid).


Build your future with O\*NET OnLine!

## Find Occupations

Bright Outlook


Bright Outlook occupations are expected to grow rapidly in the next several years, will have large numbers of job openings, or are new and emerging occupations.

Browse Bright Outlook occupations

Rapid GrowthNumerous Job OpeningsNew and EmergingAll Bright Outlook OccupationsBrowse

Career Cluster


The [National Career Clusters® Framework](https://careertech.org/career-clusters/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcareertech.org%2Fcareer-clusters%2F&t=National%20Career%20Clusters%C2%AE%20Framework&c=5f6df) serves as an organizing tool for programs, curriculum design and instruction. Career Clusters contain occupations in the same field of work that require similar skills. They can help focus plans towards obtaining the necessary knowledge, competencies, and training for success in a particular career pathway.

Browse by Career Cluster

Hot Technology


Hot technologies are software and technology skills frequently included in employer job postings.


[Discover hot technologies now](https://www.onetonline.org/search/hot_tech/)

Industry


Industries are broad groups of businesses or organizations with similar activities, products, or services.
Occupations are included based on the percentage of workers employed in that industry.

Browse by Industry

Job Family


Job Families are groups of occupations based on work performed, skills, education, training, and credentials.

Browse by Job Family

Architecture and EngineeringArts, Design, Entertainment, Sports, and MediaBuilding and Grounds Cleaning and MaintenanceBusiness and Financial OperationsCommunity and Social ServiceComputer and MathematicalConstruction and ExtractionEducational Instruction and LibraryFarming, Fishing, and ForestryFood Preparation and Serving RelatedHealthcare Practitioners and TechnicalHealthcare SupportInstallation, Maintenance, and RepairLegalLife, Physical, and Social ScienceManagementMilitary SpecificOffice and Administrative SupportPersonal Care and ServiceProductionProtective ServiceSales and RelatedTransportation and Material MovingAll Job FamiliesBrowse

Job Zone


Job Zones group occupations into one of five categories based on levels of education, experience, and training necessary to perform the occupation.

## Advanced Searches

Job Duties


Use your job duties to find occupations that perform similar work. The search uses the O\*NET database of over 19,000 occupation-specific task statements.

To begin, enter the title of your current occupation:

- Type a title or code for matches
- No quick matches found
- Search for keyword results

Go

Please enter a keyword or code.

Professional Associations


Professional associations are a great source of additional information on jobs, specialties, and industries. They also serve as an excellent starting point for networking in your career of choice. Get seamless access to professional associations by searching the O\*NET database of almost 3,000 organizations related to the occupations in the U.S. economy.

To begin your search, enter the title of an occupation:

- Type a title or code for matches
- No quick matches found
- Search for keyword results

Go

Please enter a keyword or code.

Related Activities


Use activities performed across different types of jobs to find occupations. The search uses the O\*NET database of over 2,000 detailed work activities performed across a small to moderate number of occupations.

To begin, enter the title of your current occupation:

- Type a title or code for matches
- No quick matches found
- Search for keyword results

Go

Please enter a keyword or code.

Soft Skills


Many employers value workers with soft skills—interpersonal and thinking skills needed to interact successfully with people and to perform efficiently and effectively in the workplace.

Find occupations using your current and/or future soft skills.

[Build your skills list now](https://www.onetonline.org/skills/soft/)

Technology Skills


Find occupations based on software used on the job. Learn about the technology and related skills needed to successfully perform in today’s world of work.

To begin, search for a software product or category:

# O\*NET OnLine HelpOnLine Overview

O\*NET OnLine is an application that was created for the general public to provide broad access to the O\*NET database of occupational information. O\*NET OnLine offers a variety of search options and occupational data, while [My Next Move](https://www.onetonline.org/help/onet/mynextmove) is a streamlined application for students and job seekers. Both applications were developed for the U.S. Department of Labor by the National Center for O\*NET Development.

The O\*NET database includes information on skills, abilities, knowledges, work activities, and interests associated with occupations. This information can be used to facilitate career exploration, vocational counseling, and a variety of human resources functions, such as developing job orders and position descriptions and aligning training with current workplace needs.

Information in O\*NET is available for over 900 occupations. Each occupational title and code is based on the 2018 version of the Standard Occupational Classification system.

O\*NET is a unique, powerful source for continually updated occupational information and labor market research. By using a contemporary, interactive skills-based database and a common language to describe worker skills and attributes, O\*NET transforms mountains of data into precise, focused occupational intelligence that anyone can understand easily and efficiently.

Businesses and human resources professionals use O\*NET to:

- Develop effective job descriptions quickly and easily.
- Expand the pool of quality candidates for open positions.
- Define employee and/or job-specific success factors.
- Align organizational development with workplace needs.
- Refine recruitment and training goals.
- Design competitive compensation and promotion systems.

Job seekers use O\*NET to:

- Find out which jobs fit with their interests, skills, and experience.
- Explore growth career profiles using the latest available labor market data.
- Research what it takes to get their dream job.
- Maximize earning potential and job satisfaction.
- Know what it takes to be successful in their field and in related occupations.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpO\*NET Overview

The O\*NET program is the nation's primary source of occupational information. Central to the project is the O\*NET database, containing information on hundreds of standardized and occupation-specific descriptors. The database is continually updated by surveying a broad range of workers from each occupation. Information from this freely available database forms the heart of O\*NET OnLine, the interactive application for exploring and searching occupations. The database also provides the basis for our Career Exploration Tools, a set of valuable assessment instruments for workers and students looking to find or change careers.

## Content Model: Anatomy of an occupation

Every occupation requires a different mix of knowledge, skills, and abilities, and is performed using a variety of activities and tasks. These distinguishing characteristics of an occupation are described by the [O\*NET Content Model](https://www.onetcenter.org/content.html), which encapsulates the key features of an occupation into a standardized, measurable set of variables called "descriptors". The hierarchical model starts with six domains, describing the day-to-day aspects of the job and the qualifications and interests of the typical worker. The model expands to 277 descriptors collected by the O\*NET program, with more collected by other federal agencies such as the [Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bls.gov%2F&t=Bureau%20of%20Labor%20Statistics&c=0834e).

## O\*NET-SOC Taxonomy: A spectrum of occupations

While the Content Model defines the information structure for a single occupation, the [O\*NET-SOC taxonomy](https://www.onetcenter.org/taxonomy.html) defines the set of occupations across the world of work. Based on the [Standard Occupational Classification](https://www.bls.gov/soc/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bls.gov%2Fsoc%2F&t=Standard%20Occupational%20Classification&c=67f97), the O\*NET-SOC taxonomy currently includes [923 occupations](https://www.onetcenter.org/taxonomy/2019/data_coll.html) which currently have, or are scheduled to have, data collected from job incumbents or occupation experts. To keep up with the changing occupational landscape, the taxonomy is periodically revised; the last revision was in 2019.

## Data Collection: Real-world information

The O\*NET-SOC taxonomy defines the occupations, and the Content Model outlines which information is collected; the [Data Collection program](https://www.onetcenter.org/dataCollection.html) brings these frameworks to life with results from the working public. The O\*NET database was initially populated by a group of occupation analysts; this information is augmented by ongoing surveys of each occupation's worker population and occupation experts. These statistical results are incorporated into new versions of the database on an [annual schedule](https://www.onetcenter.org/ombclearance.html#schedule), to provide up-to-date information on occupations as they evolve over time. The latest database releases are available from the [O\*NET Database](https://www.onetcenter.org/developers.html) page.

## Learn more

For a more comprehensive view of O\*NET tools and resources, please see the [O\*NET overview](https://www.onetcenter.org/overview.html) at the hub of O\*NET-related information, the [O\*NET Resource Center](https://www.onetcenter.org/).

# Browse by Career Cluster

The [National Career Clusters® Framework](https://careertech.org/career-clusters/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcareertech.org%2Fcareer-clusters%2F&t=National%20Career%20Clusters%C2%AE%20Framework&c=5f6df) serves as an organizing tool for programs, curriculum design and instruction. Career Clusters contain occupations in the same field of work that require similar skills. They can help focus plans towards obtaining the necessary knowledge, competencies, and training for success in a particular career pathway.

New Career Cluster:Advanced ManufacturingConstructionSupply Chain & TransportationArts, Entertainment, & DesignHospitality, Events, & TourismFinancial ServicesEducationHealthcare & Human ServicesPublic Service & SafetyAgricultureEnergy & Natural ResourcesDigital TechnologyManagement & EntrepreneurshipMarketing & SalesAll Career ClustersGo

# O\*NET OnLine HelpMy Next Move

![My Next Move](https://www.onetonline.org/image/mynextmove_screen1.png)

[Visit My Next Move](https://www.mynextmove.org/)

[My Next Move](https://www.mynextmove.org/) is an interactive tool for job seekers and students to learn more about their career options. The site has tasks, skills, salary information, and more for over 900 different careers. Users can find careers through keyword search; by browsing industries that employ different types of workers; or through the O\*NET Interest Profiler, a tool that offers personalized career suggestions based on a person's interests and level of work experience.

While O\*NET OnLine offers the widest range of search options and career reports, My Next Move is a streamlined application with key O\*NET information for job seekers. The guided approach helps career explorers find the information they need without being overwhelmed. Career reports also link back to O\*NET OnLine, for those interested in learning more about a specific career.

Career counselors and other professionals who work with the job-seeking public will find both applications to be valuable resources, as they are meant as complementary tools for different audiences.

Visit [My Next Move](https://www.mynextmove.org/) now!

# O\*NET OnLine HelpFind Occupations

**Find Occupations** enables you to locate O\*NET-SOC occupations using several methods:

- **[Browse Bright Outlook Occupations](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_bright)** displays occupations that are expected to grow rapidly in the next several years, will have large numbers of job openings, or are new and emerging occupations.

- **[Browse by Career Cluster](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_career)** displays occupations in the same field of work that require similar skills.

- **[Hot Technologies](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_hot)** displays requirements frequently included in employer job postings.

- **[Browse by Industry](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_ind)** explores occupations based on employment in industries. Industries are broad groups of businesses or organizations with similar activities, products, or services.

- **[Browse by Job Family](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_family)** displays groups of occupations based on work performed, skills, education, training, and credentials.

- **[Browse by Job Zone](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_zone)** lists occupations in five categories based on levels of education, experience, and training necessary to perform the occupation.

- **[Browse STEM Occupations](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_stem)** displays occupations that require education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.

- **[See All Occupations](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/browse_all)** displays all occupations in the current O\*NET-SOC taxonomy.

## O*NET Occupation Details
[![O*NET OnLine](https://www.onetonline.org/image/online-header.svg)](https://www.onetonline.org/)

Occupation keyword search

- Type a title or code for matches
- No quick matches found
- Search for keyword results

Go

# O\*NET OnLine HelpDetails Report

The **Details** report will display **all descriptors** for the selected occupation, definitions of descriptors, and a [rating](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales) of how important each descriptor is to the occupation. It also provides **Save Table** functionality to use occupation information in word processing, spreadsheet, or database programs.

The **Details** report includes: [1](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/details#foot1)

- **Occupation code, title, and definition**
- **Sample of Reported Job Titles** -
Examples of job titles provided by incumbent workers are displayed.

- **Occupation-Specific Information**  - **Tasks** -
      Tasks are specific work activities that can be unique for each occupation.

  - **Technology Skills** \- Technology Skills provide examples of software that workers may use. Includes **Hot Technology** \- technology requirements frequently included across all employer job postings - and **In Demand** \- technology requirements frequently included in employer job postings for a particular occupation.

  - **Tools Used** -
    Tools Used provides information of machines, equipment, and tools that workers may use.
- **Occupational Requirements**  - **Work Activities** -
      Work Activities summarize the kinds of tasks that may be performed across multiple
      occupations.

  - **Detailed Work Activities (DWAs)** -
    DWAs provide information on the common work activities required across occupations. These cross-occupational descriptors are less specific than Tasks, which are occupationally specific, and DWAs provide information on the common work activities required across occupations. They are provided within each of the more general Work Activities with which they are associated.

  - **Work Context** -
    Work Context refers to physical and social factors that influence the nature of
    work.
- **Experience Requirements**  - **Job Zone** -
      Occupations with similar experience, education, and training requirements are grouped together into one of the five [Job Zones](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/zones). Ratings for [SVP](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/svp) are also provided.

  - **Training & Credentials** -
    Find relevant training programs, certifications, licenses, and registered apprenticeships for this occupation.
- **Worker Requirements**  - **Skills** -
      Skills are developed capacities that facilitate learning and the performance of
      activities that occur across jobs.

  - **Knowledge** -
    Knowledges are organized sets of principles and facts that apply to a wide range
    of situations.

  - **Education** -
    Summary data on the level of education required for this occupation.
- **Worker Characteristics**  - **Abilities** -
      Abilities are enduring attributes of an individual that influence performance.

  - **Interests** -
    Interests indicate a person's preferences for work environments and outcomes.

  - **Work Values** -
    Work Values are global aspects of work that are important to a person's satisfaction.

  - **Work Styles** -
    Work Styles are personal characteristics that can affect how well someone does a job.
- **Workforce Characteristics**  - **Wages & Employment Trends** -
      Summary national wage and employment data is provided here along with search options for state specific data. (Source: [Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bls.gov%2F&t=Bureau%20of%20Labor%20Statistics&c=0834e))

  - **Job Openings** -
    Search for job postings relevant to this occupation.
- **More Information**  - **Related Occupations** -
      Similar occupations based on what people do, what they know, and what they are called.

  - **Sources of Additional Information** -
    Selected sources are listed to provide additional information on related jobs, specialties, and/or industries.

Except as noted, report data comes from the [O\*NET Database](https://www.onetcenter.org/database.html). See [External Data Sources](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/datasources) for more information.

[Ratings and standardized scores](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales) are provided for:
Tasks, Work Activities, Work Context, Skills, Knowledge, Abilities, Interests, Work Values, and Work Styles.

Many sections of the Details report show the ten most important descriptors initially. A button at the top of the section indicates the total number available to see. To show all descriptors, click the button with the  chevron icon.

## Related Occupations

When the Related occupations icon appears next to an item, you can click it to see a list of related occupations. For example, selecting the Related occupations icon next to a particular skill shows occupations where that skill is an important part of the work. Click on any listed occupation to see its full Summary report.

## Save Table

Most sections include a "save table" option that lets you view or download the data as an XLSX (Microsoft Excel) or CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file. An XLSX file is readable by Microsoft Excel and some other spreadsheet applications. A CSV file contains the values in a table as a series of text lines organized so that each column value is separated by a comma from the next column's value and each row starts a new line. Generally spreadsheet or relational database applications can read CSV files.

## Data Collection Information

The data in O\*NET OnLine is regularly updated as part of an ongoing data collection program. In the upper right hand corner of the report, a link is provided to information regarding the data source and date of update. (See: [Data Collection Information](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/data))

1
With few exceptions, the report will include all of the items listed and described. Report exceptions, such as "Military Occupations", will be brief. In the example given, the O\*NET Data Collection Program does not include "Military Occupations". Exceptions such as this will be noted. In all cases, the full range of available occupational information will be provided.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpBrowse by O\*NET Data

O\*NET Data descriptors refer to categories of occupational information collected and available for O\*NET-SOC occupations. You can browse by several categories:

- Abilities
- Interests
- Knowledge
- Skills (Basic, or Cross-Functional)
- Work Activities
- Work Context
- Work Styles
- Work Values

In the example below, the user decided to browse by Knowledge. The first screen shows Knowledge descriptors (indicated by the list icon), organized into folders (indicated by the Folder icon).

Click on any folder item to show its contents; click again to close it. Click the "Expand all" or "Collapse all" buttons at the top to open or close all folders at once. To make the list more compact, click the "Hide descriptions" button at the top.

On each descriptor screen, you can:

- See specific examples of the level needed in the **Level examples** section, for elements rated on the Level scale. See [Scales, Ratings, and Standardized Scores](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales) for more information about the Level scale.
- Filter the occupations to show only those in a selected [Job Zone](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/zones) by clicking one of the **Show Job Zones** buttons.
- Sort the occupation list by clicking any column header. Click the header a second time to reverse the sort order.

For any occupation listed, select its title to see more information about the corresponding occupation. # O\*NET OnLine HelpHot Technologies

**Hot Technologies** are requirements frequently included across all employer job postings. These 150+ software skills are often in demand across a range of occupations. As shown in the example below, all hot technologies, along with tools to explore and filter the list, are available from the starting screen:

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/search/hot_tech/)

- Narrow down the list by typing in the **Find in list** field. Only technology names containing the text you enter will be shown. The list and count of matched items will update as you type.

To discover occupations associated with a chosen technology, click its name within the list. In the example below, the user clicked "Microsoft Visual Basic for Applications VBA" to see examples of associated occupations:

# O\*NET OnLine HelpJob Duties Custom List

Use your job duties to find occupations that perform similar work, with the **Job Duties Custom List** feature. This search uses the O\*NET database of over 19,000 occupation-specific task statements.

The first step is to identify your current occupation, to use as a starting point for your search. In the following example, the user enters "biomedical engineer".

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/search/task/?t=biomedical%20engineer)

- Type a title or code for matches
- No quick matches found
- Search for keyword results

Go

[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/search/task/compare/17-2031.00?d=8975&d=8979)

## 1Closely Related Task

- Design software to control robotic systems for applications, such as military defense or manufacturing.

## 2Less Related Tasks

- Conduct research on robotic technology to create new robotic systems or system capabilities.
- Conduct research into the feasibility, design, operation, or performance of robotic mechanisms, components, or systems, such as planetary rovers, multiple mobile robots, reconfigurable robots, or man-machine interactions.

## 24Full Task List

Click on any section header to show or hide the task statements in that section.

- **Closely related tasks** are linked to the same Detailed Work Activity (DWA) as one of your selected task statements. The O\*NET Database contains over 2,000 detailed work activities performed across a small to moderate number of occupations.

- **Less related tasks** are linked to the same Intermediate Work Activity (IWA) as one of your selected task statements. The O\*NET Database contains over 300 of these more general activities common to many occupations.

- **Full task list** shows every task relevant to the occupation. If you cannot see yourself performing these activities, you may wish to consider another occupation.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpBrowse by Industry

Industries are broad groups of businesses or organizations with similar activities, products, or services. Using the Browse by Industry option, you can select from several industries, or self-employed occupations. Occupations are considered part of an industry based on their employment. In the example that follows, “Health Care and Social Assistance” is selected from the pull-down menu.

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/find/industry?x=62)

New Industry:Accommodation and Food ServicesAdministrative and Support ServicesAgriculture, Forestry, Fishing, and HuntingArts, Entertainment, and RecreationConstructionEducational ServicesFinance and InsuranceGovernmentHealth Care and Social AssistanceInformationManagement of Companies and EnterprisesManufacturingMining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas ExtractionOther Services (Except Public Administration)Professional, Scientific, and Technical ServicesReal Estate and Rental and LeasingRetail TradeTransportation and WarehousingUtilitiesWholesale TradeAll IndustriesGo

The subsequent screen provides a list of occupations where at least 10% of workers are employed within the specified industry. The display also displays projected employment statistics from the [Bureau of Labor and Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bls.gov%2F&t=Bureau%20of%20Labor%20and%20Statistics&c=da007).

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/find/industry?i=62)

- Export the full list of occupations to Excel or CSV with the **Save Table** links.
- Sort the occupation list by clicking any column header. Click the header a second time to reverse the sort order.

In the table, **Projected Growth** represents the estimated change in total employment over the projections period 2023-2033 for the US nationwide. Projected Growth categories are:

- Much faster than average (9% or higher)
- Faster than average (6% to 8%)
- Average (3% to 5%)
- Little or no change
- Decline (-1% or lower)

**Projected Job Openings** represents the total estimated openings due to growth and net replacement, over the ten-year period 2023-2033 for the US nationwide.

Should you not identify your occupation of interest in the selected industry, you can immediately re-select another industry from the accompanying pull-down menu. You can also view O\*NET-SOC occupations with significant employment in any of the industries, by choosing “All Industries” from the pull-down menu.

For any occupation listed, select its title to see more information about the corresponding occupation. For more information on these options, see OnLine Help for [Summary](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/summary), [Details](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/details), or [Custom](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/custom) Report.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpBrowse by Career Cluster

The National Career Clusters® Framework serves as an organizing tool for programs, curriculum design and instruction. Career Clusters contain occupations in the same field of work that require similar skills. They can help focus plans towards obtaining the necessary knowledge, competencies, and training for success in a particular career pathway.

The organization, clusters, sub-clusters, descriptions, example programs of study, and linkages to SOC occupations are sourced from [National Career Clusters® Framework](https://careertech.org/career-clusters) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcareertech.org%2Fcareer-clusters&t=National%20Career%20Clusters%C2%AE%20Framework&c=71e12) by Advance CTE (2024 edition). Linkages to O\*NET-SOC detailed occupations are developed by the National Center for O\*NET Development.

In the example that follows, “Financial Services” is selected from the pull-down menu.

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/find/career?c=030100)

New Career Cluster:Advanced ManufacturingConstructionSupply Chain & TransportationArts, Entertainment, & DesignHospitality, Events, & TourismFinancial ServicesEducationHealthcare & Human ServicesPublic Service & SafetyAgricultureEnergy & Natural ResourcesDigital TechnologyManagement & EntrepreneurshipMarketing & SalesAll Career ClustersGo

The subsequent screen provides a list of occupations that require similar skills in the field of Financial Services.

- Export the full list of occupations to Excel or CSV with the **Save Table** links.
- Sort the occupation list by clicking any column header. Click the header a second time to reverse the sort order.

Should you not identify your occupation of interest in the selected Career Cluster, you can immediately re-select another cluster from the accompanying pull-down menu. You can also view O\*NET-SOC occupations in any cluster by choosing “All Career Clusters” from the pull-down menu.

For any occupation listed, select its title to see more information about the corresponding occupation. For more information on these options, see OnLine Help for [Summary](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/summary), [Details](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/details), or [Custom](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/custom) Report.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpScales, Ratings, and Standardized Scores

## Overview

Each descriptor in O\*NET OnLine is associated with a scale, such as Importance, Level, and Extent of the activity. Each scale has a minimum and maximum value (e.g., Importance: 1 - 5; Level: 0 - 7). Because each of these scales covers a different numerical range, a descriptor mean of 3.0 signifies something different in each scale. In order to simplify interpretation, descriptor means have been standardized to a scale ranging from 0 to 100. (See: [Standardized Scores](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales#score))

To make sense of the different rankings, you need to understand the significance of the scale. Some people find it particularly difficult to understand the difference between Importance and Level. As an example, consider skills. While the same skill can be important for a variety of occupations, the amount or level of the skill needed in those occupations can differ dramatically. For example, the skill "speaking" is important for both lawyers and paralegals. However, lawyers (who frequently argue cases before judges and juries) are required to have a higher Level of speaking skill, while paralegals only need an average Level of this skill.

Users are encouraged to select "show scale anchors" on the [Custom Report menu](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/custom) to help with interpretation.

## Definitions of Scales by Domain [1](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales\#foot1)

| Scale | Domains | Definition |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Importance | Tasks [2](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales#foot2), Knowledge, Skills, Abilities, Work Activities, and Work Styles | This rating indicates the degree of importance a particular descriptor is to the occupation. The possible ratings range from "Not Important" (1) to "Extremely Important" (5). |
| Level [3](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales#foot3) | Knowledge, Skills, Abilities, and Work Activities | This rating indicates the degree, or point along a continuum, to which a particular descriptor is required or needed to perform the occupation. |
| Relevance | Tasks | The percentages reported for relevance refers to the proportion of job incumbents who rated the provided task relevant to his/her job. |
| Frequency | Tasks | Frequency refers to how often a task occurs within a given time period. Values of "frequently", "occasionally", and "rarely" are used to report the percentage of time job incumbents reported that a given task was performed.<br>- **Frequently** \- includes daily, several times a day, hourly or more<br>- **Occasionally** \- includes more than once a month, more than once a week<br>- **Rarely** \- includes once a year or less, more than once a year |
| Occupational Interest | Interests | O\*NET occupations are rated on 6 types of interests: Realistic, Investigative, Artistic, Social, Enterprising, and Conventional and are compatible with Holland's R-I-A-S-E-C Interest Structure (Holland, 1985). |
| Extent | Work Values | This rating indicates the degree to which an item affects the nature of an occupation. |
| Context | Work Context | Context includes a variety of scales with some unique and specific work context variables. |

1 **Not Available** -
Standards of data precision were applied to all updated incumbent and analyst ratings. The rating of an item for a particular occupation is suppressed or "not available" if its level of precision does not meet the minimum standard. For a detailed description of the suppression rules, see Appendices 1 and 2 of the O\*NET Data Dictionary, available on the [Database](https://www.onetcenter.org/database.html) page of the [O\*NET Resource Center](https://www.onetcenter.org/).

2
Two categories of tasks are identified.
**Core** -
tasks that are critical to the occupation. The criteria for these tasks are (a) relevance ≥ 67% and (b) a mean importance rating of ≥ 3.0.
**Supplemental** -
tasks that are less relevant and/or important to the occupation. Two sets of tasks are included in this category: (a) tasks rated ≥ 67% on relevance but < 3.0 on importance, and (b) tasks rated < 67% on relevance, regardless of mean importance.

3 **Not Relevant** -
The level rating for an item is identified as "not relevant" for a particular occupation when a majority (75% or more) of the incumbents or occupational analysts rate the corresponding importance item as "not important."

## Standardized Scores

The level and importance scales each have a different range of possible scores. Ratings on Level were collected on a 0-7 scale, and ratings on Importance were collected on a 1-5 scale. To make reports generated by O\*NET OnLine more intuitively understandable to users, descriptor average ratings were standardized to a scale ranging from 0 to 100. The equation for conversion of original ratings to standardized scores
is:

**S** = ( ( **O** \- **L**) / ( **H** \- **L**) ) \\* 100

where **S** is the standardized score, **O** is the original rating score on one of the three scales, **L** is the lowest possible score on the rating scale used, and **H** is the highest possible score on the rating scale used. For example, an original Importance rating score of 3 is converted to a standardized score of 50 (50 = \[ \[3 - 1\] / \[5 - 1\] \] \* 100). For another example, an original Level rating score of 5 is converted to a standardized score of 71 (71 = \[ \[5 - 0\] / \[7 - 0\] \] \* 100).

# O\*NET OnLine HelpBrowse by Job Family

Job Families are groups of similar occupations based on work performed and on required skills, education, training, and credentials. Using the **Browse by Job Family** option, you can select from any of the 23 Standard Occupational Classification job families. In the example that follows, “Community and Social Services” is selected from the pull-down menu in a search for the occupation of “Community Health Workers”.

Example
[view in context](https://www.onetonline.org/find/family?x=21)

New Job Family:Architecture and EngineeringArts, Design, Entertainment, Sports, and MediaBuilding and Grounds Cleaning and MaintenanceBusiness and Financial OperationsCommunity and Social ServiceComputer and MathematicalConstruction and ExtractionEducational Instruction and LibraryFarming, Fishing, and ForestryFood Preparation and Serving RelatedHealthcare Practitioners and TechnicalHealthcare SupportInstallation, Maintenance, and RepairLegalLife, Physical, and Social ScienceManagementMilitary SpecificOffice and Administrative SupportPersonal Care and ServiceProductionProtective ServiceSales and RelatedTransportation and Material MovingAll Job FamiliesGo

The subsequent screen provides a list of all occupations within the specified job family. You can sort the occupations by O\*NET-SOC Code or by Title by selecting the appropriate link.

Should you not identify your occupation of interest in the selected job family, you can immediately re-select another job family from the accompanying pull-down menu. You can also view every O\*NET-SOC occupation by choosing “All Occupations” from the pull-down menu.

For any occupation listed, select its title to see more information about the corresponding occupation. For more information on these options, see OnLine Help for [Summary](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/summary), [Details](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/details), or [Custom](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/custom) Report.

# O\*NET OnLine HelpReports Overview

O\*NET OnLine offers 3 report options: Summary, Details, and Custom.

- The **[Summary Report](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/summary)** provides an overview or snapshot of the selected occupation, focusing on the most important descriptors.

- The **[Details Report](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/details)** displays all descriptors for the selected occupation; and, where available, a rating of how important each descriptor is to the occupation.

- The **[Custom Report](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/custom)** allows you to select from 21 different content areas to generate tailored reports about occupations. In the case of selected O\*NET descriptors (e.g., Skills, Work Values, etc.), you can further control your report contents by selecting the scale to display and minimum cutoff scores. (See [Scales, Ratings and Standardized Scores](https://www.onetonline.org/help/online/scales)).

# Certification: Certified Radiology Administrator (CRA)

## Certifying Organization

[Association for Medical Imaging Management](https://www.ahra.org/Default.aspx) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ahra.org%2FDefault.aspx&t=Association%20for%20Medical%20Imaging%20Management&c=e1276)

490B Boston Post Road #101, Sudbury, MA 01776

## Description

As a medical imaging administrator, you face a number of difficult challenges. One of them is having people recognize your skills and capabilities. The Certified Radiology Administrator (CRA) designation speaks volumes about the high standards of achievement you've attained for the profession of radiology administration. The CRA is the only professional credential tailored specifically for radiology administrators, focusing on human resource management, asset resource management, fiscal management, operations management, and communication and information management-expertise you bring to the job each day. The CRA program, including the examination, is managed by the Radiology Administration Certification Commission (RACC), a self-governing body created to maintain the credential's integrity and relevance.

[More information about this certification](https://www.ahra.org/CRA/Default.aspx) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ahra.org%2FCRA%2FDefault.aspx&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=5f058)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? NoMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

## Additional Details

- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Mental Health Technician Certification (MHTC)

## Certifying Organization

[American Medical Certification Association](https://www.amcaexams.com/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amcaexams.com%2F&t=American%20Medical%20Certification%20Association&c=c13fa)

194 US Highway 46 East Fairfield, NJ 07004

## Description

A Mental Health Technician Certification (MHTC) also known as a psychiatric aide participates in both the planning and implementing of individual patient treatment plans.

[More information about this certification](https://www.amcaexams.com/exam-candidates/certification-exam/mental-health-technician-certification/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amcaexams.com%2Fexam-candidates%2Fcertification-exam%2Fmental-health-technician-certification%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=2ed88)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? NoOral or Written Exam Required? Yes

## Exam Details

Online Exam; Third Party Exam Center

The test is comprised of 100 questions in Mental Health:The breakdown is as follows: Process and Procedure, Law and Ethics, Psychological development, pharmacology, practice settings, and safety/ infection control. Allotted time for examinees is 2 hours.

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

## Additional Details

- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Diplomate of the ACVPM

## Certifying Organization

[American College of Veterinary Preventive Medicine](https://acvpm.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Facvpm.org%2F&t=American%20College%20of%20Veterinary%20Preventive%20Medicine&c=fd9a0)

## Description

A veterinarian who has satisfied the requirements as to character, training, experience and competence in veterinary preventive medicine including satisfactory completion of the certifying examination is eligible for certification. Certification as a Diplomate of the ACVPM is complete upon receiving a confirmatory vote by a majority of the members of the Executive Board.

[More information about this certification](https://acvpm.org/page/acvpm-exam) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Facvpm.org%2Fpage%2Facvpm-exam&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=9a1ef)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? Yes

## Certification Type

### Specialty

The certification corresponds to a specialty within a recognized occupation. For example, Oncology Nurse and Pediatric Nurse are specialties within the nursing field, so Certified Oncology Nurse and Certified Pediatric Nurse would be classified as specialty certifications.

# Certification: Ophthalmic Scribe Certification (OSC)

## Certifying Organization

[Joint Commission on Allied Health Personnel in Ophthalmology](https://www.jcahpo.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jcahpo.org&t=Joint%20Commission%20on%20Allied%20Health%20Personnel%20in%20Ophthalmology&c=26af5)

2025 Woodlane Drive, St. Paul, MN 551252995

## Description

The Ophthalmic Scribe Certification (OSC) is designed to test the knowledge of creating and maintaining patient medical records under

the supervision of an ophthalmologist. These records include the documentation of a comprehensive patient history, physical examination,

medications, lab results, and other essential patient information. This examination is CMS Stage 2 Eligible Professional Meaningful Use Core

Measure compliant.

[More information about this certification](https://www.jcahpo.org/certification-recertification/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jcahpo.org%2Fcertification-recertification%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=878fc)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? NoMore than two years of work experience required? NoOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? NoRenew through Re-Examination? YesRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? NoDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Exam Details

Online Exam

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

## Additional Details

- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Certified Employee Retention Specialist (CERS)

## Certifying Organization

[National Association of Personnel Services](https://www.naps360.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.naps360.org%2F&t=National%20Association%20of%20Personnel%20Services&c=53e1e)

3133 Mount Vernon Avenue, Alexandria, VA 22305

## Description

The NAPS Certified Employee Retention Specialist credentialing process empowers search professionals to take a new look at search so they can learn how to become that strategic partner who can enhance the stability and profitability of their client's human capital. CERS training teaches you the key drivers of employee retention as well as the long term impact of high retention on productivity, morale, and overall organizational profitability. This knowledge will allow you to confidentially assess your client's retention issues and advise them with specific recommendations as their trusted retention advisor. Becoming this trusted advisor, you will find increased opportunities for your search and consulting services.

[More information about this certification](https://www.naps360.org/page/CERSCertification) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.naps360.org%2Fpage%2FCERSCertification&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=68d31)

# Certification: Global Mobility Specialist (GMS)

## Certifying Organization

[Employee Relocation Council](https://www.worldwideerc.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldwideerc.org%2F&t=Employee%20Relocation%20Council&c=40957)

1720 N Street NW, Washington, DC 20036

## Description

The purpose of Worldwide ERC's Certified Relocation Professional certification is to encourage members working in specific aspects of employee relocation to gain extensive and useful knowledge of all aspects of employee relocation. A major purpose of this certification is the achievement of a common and universal understanding of the entire employee relocation field and recognition of those professionals who demonstrate mastery.

[More information about this certification](https://www.worldwideerc.org/gms-detail) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldwideerc.org%2Fgms-detail&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=1aa3b)

## Q&A

More than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

# Certification: GIAC Reverse Engineering Malware (GREM)

## Certifying Organization

[Global Information Assurance Certification](https://www.giac.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.giac.org%2F&t=Global%20Information%20Assurance%20Certification&c=f7533)

## Description

The GIAC Reverse Engineering Malware (GREM) certification is designed for technologists who protect the organization from malicious code. GREM-certified technologists possess the knowledge and skills to reverse-engineer malicious software (malware) that targets common platforms, such as Microsoft Windows and web browsers. These individuals know how to examine inner-workings of malware in the context of forensic investigations, incident response, and Windows system administration. Become more valuable to your employer and/or customers by highlighting your cutting-edge malware analysis skills through the GREM certification.

[More information about this certification](https://www.giac.org/certifications/reverse-engineering-malware-grem/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.giac.org%2Fcertifications%2Freverse-engineering-malware-grem%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=82154)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 4 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? YesRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? NoDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? Yes

## Exam Details

Online Exam; Third Party Exam Center

All GIAC Certification exams are web-based and required to be proctored. There are two proctoring options: remote proctoring through ProctorU, and onsite proctoring through PearsonVUE. Click [here](https://www.giac.org/knowledge-base/proctor/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.giac.org%2Fknowledge-base%2Fproctor%2F&t=here&c=5ad99) for more information.

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

## Additional Details

- This certification is considered in demand.
- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Certified Emergency Manager (CEM)

## Certifying Organization

[International Association of Emergency Managers](https://www.iaem.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iaem.org&t=International%20Association%20of%20Emergency%20Managers&c=ea995)

201 Park Washington Court Falls Church, VA 22046-4527

## Description

A Certified Emergency Manager® (CEM®) has the knowledge, skills and ability to effectively manage a comprehensive emergency management program. A CEM® has a working knowledge of all the basic tenets of emergency management, including mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery. A CEM® has experience and knowledge of interagency and community-wide participation in planning, coordination and management functions designed to improve emergency management capabilities. A CEM® can effectively accomplish the goals and objectives of any emergency management program in all environments with little or no additional training orientation.

[More information about this certification](https://www.iaem.org/Certification/Getting-Started) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iaem.org%2FCertification%2FGetting-Started&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=276a0)

1627 Eye Street, NW, Suite 600, Washington, DC 20006 USA

## Description

Certification as a Professional Traffic Operations Engineer (PTOE) is a powerful demonstration of requisite knowledge, skill and ability in the specialized application of traffic operations engineering. The certification process builds on and supports the practice of professional engineering registration. It is a long-term investment in one's professional career, which can be presented with pride!

[More information about this certification](https://www.tpcb.org/certification/ptoe/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tpcb.org%2Fcertification%2Fptoe%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=3ce8a)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? NoRenew through Re-Examination? NoRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

## Additional Details

- This certification is accredited by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies (NCCA).
- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Multiple Sclerosis Certified Specialist (MSCS)

## Certifying Organization

[The Consortium of Multiple Sclerosis Centers](https://www.mscare.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mscare.org%2F&t=The%20Consortium%20of%20Multiple%20Sclerosis%20Centers&c=cf804)

## Description

Certification is intended to promote quality and consistent care to those living with multiple sclerosis by: Recognizing the many specialists involved with MS care delivery Establishing a basic knowledge required for practice in the fields of MS Encouraging continuous learning so that those in MS care sustain a basic level of knowledge about the disease and its implications.

[More information about this certification](https://www.mscare.org/general/custom.asp?page=about_mscs) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mscare.org%2Fgeneral%2Fcustom.asp%3Fpage%3Dabout_mscs&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=50b5b)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 5 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? YesRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Specialty

The certification corresponds to a specialty within a recognized occupation. For example, Oncology Nurse and Pediatric Nurse are specialties within the nursing field, so Certified Oncology Nurse and Certified Pediatric Nurse would be classified as specialty certifications.

# Certification: Distributed Generation Certified Professional (DGCP)

## Certifying Organization

[Association of Energy Engineers](https://www.aeecenter.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aeecenter.org%2F&t=Association%20of%20Energy%20Engineers&c=e4595)

3168 Mercer University Drive. Atlanta, Georgia 30341

## Description

AEE's Distributed Generation Certified Professional (DGCP) program is designed to provide recognition for professionals who have distinguished themselves as leaders in the distributed generation field. The designation DGCP identifies individuals who have demonstrated high levels of experience, competence, proficiency, and ethical fitness, bringing to their professional activities the full scope of knowledge essential to the effective development and management to today's distributed generation projects.

[More information about this certification](https://www.aeecenter.org/certifications/certifications/distributed-generation-certified-professional) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aeecenter.org%2Fcertifications%2Fcertifications%2Fdistributed-generation-certified-professional&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=47ba7)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesEither training or work experience required, but not both? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? YesRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

# Certification: Online Marketing Certified Professional (OMCP)

## Certifying Organization

[Online Marketing Certified Professionals](https://omcp.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fomcp.org%2F&t=Online%20Marketing%20Certified%20Professionals&c=71dc6)

548 Market Street San Francisco, CA 94104

## Description

The OMCP designation indicates that you have demonstrated the knowledge,

skills, and competencies necessary to practice online marketing as a professional, requiring minimal or no supervision.

To be eligible for a OMCP Credential, you must first meet specific

education and marketing experience requirements. The final step to becoming

an OMCP is passing a three part multiple-choice examination that tests

conceptual knowledge across multiple online marketing disciplines, plus two additional sections that test for generally accepted practices in Content Marketing, Conversion Rate Optimization, Email Marketing, Mobile Marketing, Digital Advertising, Search Engine Optimization (SEO), Social Media Marketing,

and Web Analytics.

[More information about this certification](https://omcp.org/omcp-certification/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fomcp.org%2Fomcp-certification%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=8b52a)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 2 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

# Certification: Fundamental Payroll Certification (FPC)

## Certifying Organization

[American Payroll Association](https://www.americanpayroll.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.americanpayroll.org%2F&t=American%20Payroll%20Association&c=a8dea)

711 Navarro Street, Suite 100, San Antonio,TX 78205-1721

## Description

The Fundamental Payroll Certification (FPC) is open to all those who wish to demonstrate a baseline of payroll competency. The FPC is designed for: Entry-level Payroll Professionals, <br>Sales Professionals/Consultants serving the payroll industry, <br>Systems Analysts/Engineers writing payroll programs, and <br>Payroll Service Bureau Client Representatives. APA membership is not required.

[More information about this certification](https://www.americanpayroll.org/education-certification/certification/fundamental-payroll-certification-(fpc)) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.americanpayroll.org%2Feducation-certification%2Fcertification%2Ffundamental-payroll-certification-%28fpc%29&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=a2339)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? NoMore than two years of work experience required? NoOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? YesRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

## Additional Details

- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Certified Food Protection Professional (CFPP)

## Certifying Organization

[Association of Nutrition and Food Service Professionals](https://www.anfponline.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.anfponline.org%2F&t=Association%20of%20Nutrition%20and%20Food%20Service%20Professionals&c=84cfe)

406 Surrey Woods Dr., St. Charles, IL 60174

## Description

A certified dietary manager, certified food protection professional (CDM, CFPP) has the education, training, and experience to competently perform the responsibilities of a dietary manager and has proven this by passing a nationally-recognized credentialing exam and fulfilling the requirements needed to maintain certified status.

[More information about this certification](https://www.anfponline.org/become-a-cdm/cdm-cfpp-credential) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.anfponline.org%2Fbecome-a-cdm%2Fcdm-cfpp-credential&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=f2c8d)

## Q&A

Either training or work experience required, but not both? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

## Additional Details

- This certification is accredited by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies (NCCA).
- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Certified Customer Service Specialist (CSS)

## Certifying Organization

[ETA International](https://www.etai.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.etai.org%2F&t=ETA%20International&c=97642)

5 Depot Street, Greencastle, IN 46135

## Description

The Customer Service Specialist (CSS) is a soft skills certification that validates one's work skills through employability concepts. Though developed to meet the role of an evolving service oriented electronics technician, CSS is relevant to every industry, employer and employee. Topics included are safety, ethics, respect, teamwork, communication, telephone and email techniques, problem solving, interpersonal relationships, and sales and marketing.

[More information about this certification](https://etai.org/workforce_readiness.html#CSS) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fetai.org%2Fworkforce_readiness.html%23CSS&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=f2529)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? NoMore than two years of work experience required? NoOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? NoRenew through Re-Examination? NoRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? NoDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Exam Details

Online Exam; Third Party Exam Center

Certification exams available online or through a local exam center, more information available here: [https://etai.org/test\_sites.html](https://etai.org/test_sites.html) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fetai.org%2Ftest_sites.html&t=https%3A%2F%2Fetai.org%2Ftest_sites.html&c=9248a)

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

## Additional Details

- This certification is related to military occupational specialties.

# Certification: Certified U.S. Import Compliance Officer (CUSICO)

## Certifying Organization

[International Import Export Institute](https://www.iiei.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iiei.org%2F&t=International%20Import%20Export%20Institute&c=ffd9c)

19820 North 7th Street, Suite #100, Phoenix, AZ 85024 USA

## Description

Demonstrates your compliance knowledge of the U.S. Customs & Border Protection's Regulations and competency as an Import Compliance Officer. The Certified U.S. Import Compliance Officer Certification develops an advanced working knowledge of importing, emphasizing compliance with U.S. Customs Regulations. Introduces terms of sale used in international trade, with a focus on all thirteen items of sale under Incoterms 2010. Demonstrates the advantages of partnering with the U.S. Government's Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism Program (C-TPAT), which works with importers on how to reduce security-orientated inspections by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Instructor designs discussions and assignments to guide the student with practical applications of the C-TPAT requirements. Explains the forces that shape business ethics and explores topics of managing importation of goods into a country.

[More information about this certification](https://www.iiei.org/certified-u-s-import-compliance-officer-cusico/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iiei.org%2Fcertified-u-s-import-compliance-officer-cusico%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=d9051)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? NoRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? NoDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? No

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.

# Certification: Certified Electron Microscopy Technologist (CEMT)

## Certifying Organization

[Microscopy Society of America](https://www.microscopy.org/index.cfm) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.microscopy.org%2Findex.cfm&t=Microscopy%20Society%20of%20America&c=14bab)

230 East Ohio, Suite 400 Chicago, IL 60611

## Description

The Microscopy Society of America (MSA), the world's largest professional association of microscopists, provides the only certification of technologists in biological transmission electron microscopy available in the Americas. The program was instituted in 1978 to establish standards for technical skills. In addition to assuring employers that certified technologists are technically proficient, certification can be important in determining job classification, salary level, and potential for advancement or promotion. Many consider certification to be a key benchmark in their professional development.

[More information about this certification](https://www.microscopy.org/education/programs.cfm) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.microscopy.org%2Feducation%2Fprograms.cfm&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=9aa0e)

# Certification: ACTFL Reading Proficiency Test (RPT)

## Certifying Organization

American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages

1001 N. Fairfax Street, Suite 200 Alexandria, VA 22314

## Description

The Reading Proficiency Test (RPT) is a proctored, online, proficiency-based test for the global assessment of reading ability in a language. It is an assessment of the interpretive communication mode as described in the World-Readiness Standards for Learning Languages. RPTs measure how well a person spontaneously understands written language as described in the ACTFL or ILR rating scales without access to dictionaries or reference grammars.

The RPTs assess general language proficiency, not what is learned in a specific program, class, school, or university. It is not tied to a particular teaching method or curriculum. Rather than assessing what you "know" about the language, the RPT is an assessment of how well you can understand the written language.

[More information about this certification](https://www.actfl.org/actfl-assessments/actfl-postsecondary-assessments/rpt) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.actfl.org%2Factfl-assessments%2Factfl-postsecondary-assessments%2Frpt&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=7f22e)

## Q&A

# Certification: Sun Certified Systems Administrator

## Certifying Organization

[Oracle Corporation](https://www.oracle.com/index.html) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.oracle.com%2Findex.html&t=Oracle%20Corporation&c=c3202)

500 Oracle Parkway, Redwood Shores, CA 94065

## Description

The OCA and OCP, Solaris 11 System Administrator certifications are designed to begin with individuals who possess a strong foundation in the administration of the Oracle Solaris 11 Operating System at the OCA level and who, at the OCP level have expanded their mastery of the administration of the Oracle Solaris 11 Operating System from the base-level of skills and have a fundamental understanding of the UNIX operating system, commands, and utilities.

The OCA certification covers essential system administration skills such as managing local disk devices, managing file systems, installing and removing Solaris packages and patches, performing system boot procedures and system processes. The OCP certification covers system administration skills such as configuring network interfaces, managing swap configurations, crash dumps, and core files. Certification provides a solid foundation on which to base continued learning. Up-to-date training and field experience are recommended.

Oracle Certifications differentiate candidates in the marketplace by providing a competitive edge through proven expertise.

[More information about this certification](https://education.oracle.com/oracle-certified-associate-oracle-solaris-11-system-administrator/trackp_202) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Feducation.oracle.com%2Foracle-certified-associate-oracle-solaris-11-system-administrator%2Ftrackp_202&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=daf51)

# Certification: Certified Community Action Professional (CCAP)

## Certifying Organization

[Community Action Partnership](https://communityactionpartnership.com/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcommunityactionpartnership.com%2F&t=Community%20Action%20Partnership&c=7fbe7)

1140 Connecticut Avenue NW Suite 1210 Washington DC, 20036

## Description

Certification is designed for current and emerging managers or leaders in the Community Action Profession. To achieve certification, employment in either a CAA, a delegate agency or sub-grantee of a CAA, a CSBG eligible entity, a state or regional association office, or a state community services program office is required.

[More information about this certification](https://communityactionpartnership.com/ccap/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcommunityactionpartnership.com%2Fccap%2F&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=e5aeb)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? NoMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 4 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? No

## Certification Type

### Core

1. The certification does not have a minimum education level or has an education level below a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree and the certification does not have a minimum requirement for work experience or requires two or less years of work experience.
2. The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher, but has a work experience requirement of less than 2 years of work experience.
3. The certification has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years but does not require a two-year Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree.

# Certification: Certified Health Service Administrator (CHSA)

## Certifying Organization

[American Correctional Association](https://www.aca.org/) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aca.org%2F&t=American%20Correctional%20Association&c=eefdf)

206 North Washington Street. Suite 200 Alexandria, VA 22314

## Description

The Certified Health Service Administrator credential is for Health Service Administrators. They are management staff who contribute to the development of policy and procedures, are responsible for their implementation, and have authority over staff members. They plan, direct, coordinate and supervise the health care system.

[More information about this certification](https://www.aca.org/ACA_Member/Professional%20Development/Certification/Certification_Types_and_Levels/ACA/ACA_Member/Certification/Certification_Types_and_Levels.aspx) [external site](https://www.onetonline.org/shared/exit?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.aca.org%2FACA_Member%2FProfessional%2520Development%2FCertification%2FCertification_Types_and_Levels%2FACA%2FACA_Member%2FCertification%2FCertification_Types_and_Levels.aspx&t=More%20information%20about%20this%20certification&c=541a9)

## Q&A

More than two years of education or training after high school required? YesMore than two years of work experience required? YesOral or Written Exam Required? YesRenewal Required?Every 3 Year(s)Renew through Continuing Educational Units(CEU)? YesRenew through Re-Examination? NoRenew through Continuing Professional Development(CPD)? YesDoes applicant have choice of at least two options from above for renewal (CEU, CPD, or exam)? Yes

## Certification Type

### Advanced

The certification has an education level of an Associates of Arts or Associates of Sciences degree or higher and has a work experience requirement of more than 2 years, or requires obtaining a ‘core’ level certification from the same organization.
